patterns.pattern: First-time contributors (0 prior PRs) with large size label face deterministic rejection despite high-priority categories
Missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) imposes consistent 7-8% confidence penalty across all author types
XS and S size labels provide strongest compensatory signal for weak author credentials, correlating with 26-28% merge rates and +2-4% boost over baseline
High-priority categories (agents, gateway) provide +15-25% baseline uplift independent of author history
Fix-type changes receive consistent +10-20% merge boost over feature-type additions
Authors with 0% historical merge rate across 2+ prior PR attempts face rejection pattern unless compensated by explicit credibility labels or XS size
Multi-category scope from first-time/low-credibility authors imposes -25-30% penalty (scope creep risk signal)
Authors with 50+ prior PRs retain moderate merge likelihood (25-30%) even with below-baseline merge rates, due to persistence/commitment signal
Trusted-contributor and experienced-contributor labels provide +5-15% credibility boost and can override below-baseline author merge rates
Perfect author merge history (100% across prior PRs) provides +15-25% credibility bonus even with single prior PR
Extension-related work carries elevated rejection risk (-10-15% penalty) for first-time contributors absent maintainer approval
Narrow scope (single component, focused logical change) provides consistent +5-10% merge probability boost
Large size label (L) creates deterministic rejection signal correlating with 15-20% merge rates, overriding compensatory signals from high-priority categories for weak authors
Author merge rate above baseline (>24%) demonstrates predictive capability independent of PR scope and provides +5-10% delta bonus
Multi-channel touches from weak-credibility authors impose -25-30% penalty; narrow single-component focus provides mitigation
Feature-type additions require stronger compensatory signals (maintainer labels, established author history) compared to fix-type changes
Critical-path infrastructure changes from first-time contributors face elevated scrutiny and require explicit credibility signals or size-label compensation
Author persistence (multiple prior PR attempts) partially mitigates low merge rate by +5% when accompanied by narrow scope
